name: NewYorker
text: In “Juneteenth,” one character makes a frame for the understanding of the holiday, by exhorting worshippers to approach it as something like Passover—a day of deliverance on which to tell stories that keep history alive in memory. https://t.co/YVqA1BT5cK

name: NewYorker
text: The closer an apple is to rot, the more rot it spreads—one spoiling apple speeds the rot of every apple it touches, and even of ones it doesn’t touch. https://t.co/OrgvFk1A4H

name: NewYorker
text: “This man’s life will not be in vain,” one protester said, at the site of George Floyd’s murder. “This is going worldwide. The entire world is hearing us.” https://t.co/qlzDZgHdg7

name: NewYorker
text: “At 1 A.M. the dairy sink / in your yard was a deer-glyphed megalith / caught in my headlights.” A poem by Paul Muldoon. https://t.co/Ycmz7jUjcR

name: NewYorker
text: “She had me under her spell—that beautiful, nameless girl clutching ‘With the Beatles’ to her chest.” A new short story by Haruki Murakami. https://t.co/42Ht2YsPvW

name: NewYorker
text: “Now that he is gone, where can we turn for such economy of gesture and for so compellingly steady a gaze?” Anthony Lane on the death of Ian Holm. https://t.co/M0NeRYwMDJ

name: NewYorker
text: Plywood storefronts in SoHo bear the names of black men and women who were killed by police officers, flyers calling for investigations, quotes from James Baldwin and Malcolm X, and a poem by Langston Hughes. https://t.co/2cwzHR836b
